_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SOLENIS, LLC - MILWAUKEE PLANT



RMP EXECUTUVE SUMMARY 



Solenis, LLC is dedicated to providing a safe and healthful environment for our employees, customers, and community.  To do this, we are dedicated to working toward continuous improvement in our operations to prevent pollution, reduce risks, and to enhance safety, health, and environmental performance.  By incorporating these beliefs and attitudes into the way we do things at Solenis, we take a key step forward in minimizing the environmental impact of our operations and satisfying customer needs.  

  

Solenis is a member of the American Chemistry Council (ACC) and subscribes to its Responsible Care program and holds the core values,  principles, and commitments in the Responsible Care goals listed below:





  - Operate with zero incidents. We believe that all injuries, occupational illnesses and incidents are preventable and we are committed to operating with a zero-incident culture. Our culture engages all employees and also promotes off-the-job-safety and environmental stewardship for our employees and their families. We design, build and operate our facilities to be safe, secure and protective of the environment and the local community 





  - Ensure compliance. We are committed to ensuring compliance with applicable environmental, health, safety and security laws, regulations, technical specifications and internal standards, while adhering to high ethical standards.  





  - Reduce environmental, health, safety, and security impact. We are committed to continuously improving our processes and to providing products and services that throughout their life-cycle involve minimum risk to people and the environment, while best meeting the needs of our customers. We are committed to the continual reduction of the impact of our operations and products in support of global sustainability efforts. We strive to eliminate or reduce emissions, discharges, and wastes from our operations and to promote energy

efficiency and resource conservation throughout the value chain.



FACILITY DESCRIPTION:



The Milwaukee Plant manufactures chemical additives used in the pulp and paper industry, and uses epichlorohydrin in the production of wet-strength resins.  These resins are used in paper towels, napkins, tissues, etc. so that they will not come apart easily when wet.  Epichlorohydrin is a raw material for the process and is consumed in a chemical reaction to make the product.  The plant receives epichlorohydrin in tank trucks and railroad tank cars and stores the material in a storage tank.  The storage tank is provided with a containment dike and leak detection to minimize adverse impacts from any potential leaks, releases or spills.  



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM:



The Solenis Milwaukee facility complies with the OSHA PSM rule.  As a PSM facility, Solenis completes a detailed Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) every 5 years.  The PHA seeks to identify and address potential causes of incidents before they occur.  In addition, PSM training on safe handling of equipment and chemicals is conducted every three years for all Kymene area operators and all maintenance mechanics.  Management of Change (MOC) procedures are followed to ensure that any changes that occur in the Kymene process do not have the potential to result in an increased risk of a safety incident or an accidental release. In addition, routine maintenance is conducted under the facilities preventative maintenance program to ensure that equipment critical to the safe handling of epichlorohydrin is maintained in good condition at all times. System interlocks ensure that incompatible chemicals are not mixed together.  



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



There have been no incidents involving the release of epichlorohydrin in the last 5 years that meet the criteria for inclusion in the 5-year incident history.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:



The Milwaukee Plant has a written emergency response plan and coordinates

emergency response matters with the local fire department along with the Local Emergency Planning Committee.  The Plant also coordinates with the City of Milwaukee Department Neighborhood Services to ensure all process controls, mitigation systems, and monitoring devices are in place to ensure safe handling and storage of raw materials.
